content:
StartTask StartTask Class

In this Article

Edit

A task which is run when a compute node joins a pool in the Azure Batch service, or when the compute node is rebooted or reimaged.

Properties

  • Edit
    CommandLine
    CommandLine

    Gets or sets the command line of the start task.

    [JsonProperty(PropertyName = "commandLine")]
public string CommandLine { get; set; }<JsonProperty(PropertyName:="commandLine")>
Public Property CommandLine As String

    Property Value

    • String
      String

    Remarks

    The command line does not run under a shell, and therefore cannot take advantage of shell features such as environment variable expansion. If you want to take advantage of such features, you should invoke the shell in the command line, for example using "cmd /c MyCommand" in Windows or "/bin/sh -c MyCommand" in Linux.

  • Edit
    EnvironmentSettings
    EnvironmentSettings

    Gets or sets a list of environment variable settings for the start task.

    [JsonProperty(PropertyName = "environmentSettings")]
public IList<EnvironmentSetting> EnvironmentSettings { get; set; }<JsonProperty(PropertyName:="environmentSettings")>
Public Property EnvironmentSettings As IList(Of EnvironmentSetting)

    Property Value

    • IList<EnvironmentSetting>
      IList(Of EnvironmentSetting)
  • Edit
    MaxTaskRetryCount
    MaxTaskRetryCount

    Gets or sets the maximum number of times the task may be retried.

    [JsonProperty(PropertyName = "maxTaskRetryCount")]
public int ? MaxTaskRetryCount { get; set; }<JsonProperty(PropertyName:="maxTaskRetryCount")>
Public Property MaxTaskRetryCount As Integer?

    Property Value

    • Nullable<Int32>
      Nullable(Of Int32)

    Remarks

    The Batch service retries a task if its exit code is nonzero. Note that this value specifically controls the number of retries. The Batch service will try the task once, and may then retry up to this limit. For example, if the maximum retry count is 3, Batch tries the task up to 4 times (one initial try and 3 retries). If the maximum retry count is 0, the Batch service does not retry the task. If the maximum retry count is -1, the Batch service retries the task without limit.

  • Edit
    ResourceFiles
    ResourceFiles

    Gets or sets a list of files that the Batch service will download to the compute node before running the command line.

    [JsonProperty(PropertyName = "resourceFiles")]
public IList<ResourceFile> ResourceFiles { get; set; }<JsonProperty(PropertyName:="resourceFiles")>
Public Property ResourceFiles As IList(Of ResourceFile)

    Property Value

    • IList<ResourceFile>
      IList(Of ResourceFile)
  • Edit
    UserIdentity
    UserIdentity

    Gets or sets the user identity under which the start task runs.

    [JsonProperty(PropertyName = "userIdentity")]
public UserIdentity UserIdentity { get; set; }<JsonProperty(PropertyName:="userIdentity")>
Public Property UserIdentity As UserIdentity

    Property Value

    • UserIdentity
      UserIdentity

    Remarks

    If omitted, the task runs as a non-administrative user unique to the task.

  • Edit
    WaitForSuccess
    WaitForSuccess

    Gets or sets whether the Batch service should wait for the start task to complete successfully (that is, to exit with exit code 0) before scheduling any tasks on the compute node.

    [JsonProperty(PropertyName = "waitForSuccess")]
public bool ? WaitForSuccess { get; set; }<JsonProperty(PropertyName:="waitForSuccess")>
Public Property WaitForSuccess As Boolean?

    Property Value

    • Nullable<Boolean>
      Nullable(Of Boolean)

    Remarks

    If true and the start task fails on a compute node, the Batch service retries the start task up to its maximum retry count (maxTaskRetryCount). If the task has still not completed successfully after all retries, then the Batch service marks the compute node unusable, and will not schedule tasks to it. This condition can be detected via the node state and scheduling error detail. If false, the Batch service will not wait for the start task to complete. In this case, other tasks can start executing on the compute node while the start task is still running; and even if the start task fails, new tasks will continue to be scheduled on the node. The default is false.
